rdec - regression with damped exponential correlation

Vincent J. Carey, stvjc at channing.harvard.edu

August 20, 2023

Source: vignettes/rdec.Rmd
rdec.Rmd

Introduction

The model implemented here was described in Munoz A, Carey VJ, Schouten J, Segal M, Rosner B, A parametric family of correlation structures for the analysis of longitudinal data, Biometrics 48, 733-742, September 1992. A JSTOR URL is https://www.jstor.org/stable/2532340.

We consider longitudinal responses \(y_{ij}\), \(j=1, \ldots n_i\), \(i = 1, \ldots, N\). The \(n_i\)-vector \(y_i\) has elements that are assumed ordered in time with timings recorded in \(s_{ij}\). A \(p\)-vector of predictors including an intercept is provided for each observation in \(x_{ij}\).

rdec fits the model \[ y_{ij} = x_{ij} \beta + e_{ij} \] in which the \(n_i\)-vectors \(e_{i}\) are assumed multivariate Gaussian with covariance \(\sigma^2 R(\gamma, \theta; s_i)\). For \(1 \leq g, h, \leq n_i\) the \(g,h\) element of \(R(\gamma, \theta; s_i)\) is given by \[ Corr(y_{ig}, y_{ih}) = \gamma ^ { |s_{ig} - s_{ih} |^\theta }. \] Models with \(\theta = 0\) are also called exchangeable or compound symmetry models. Models with \(\theta = 1\) correspond to first-degree autoregressions (AR(1) models). As \(\theta \rightarrow \infty\) the model approaches a first-order moving average. rdec implements maximum likelihood estimation of all parameters \(\beta\), \(\sigma\), \(\gamma\), \(\theta\). Munoz et al in the paper referenced above provide empirical evidence that members of the rdec model family can effectively approximate second-order autoregressive (AR(2)) models and AR(1) models with random intercept.

A simple simulation

The function mycov builds a correlation matrix based on the rdec model, with observation times in s.

library(MASS)
mycov = function(gam=.33, theta=.5, s=1:5) {
  d = as.matrix(dist(s, method="manhattan"))
  gam^(d^theta)
}

The model can accommodate clusters of different sizes and heterogeneous timings. Here we simulate a zero-mean model with fixed gamma and theta for common timings for all elements of N clusters in s.

simgst_bal_zeromean = function(gam, theta, s1=1:5, N=100) {
  dat = mvrnorm(N, rep(0,length(s1)), mycov(gam=gam, theta=theta, s=s1))
  mdat = reshape2::melt(dat)
  ndat = dplyr::arrange(mdat, Var1)
  rdec::rdec(value~1, id=ndat$Var1, S=ndat$Var2, data=ndat)
}

Here is the result of a single simulation.

set.seed(1234)
n1 = simgst_bal_zeromean(.33, .5)
summary(n1)
## 
## Call: rdec::rdec(formula = value ~ 1, id = ndat$Var1, S = ndat$Var2, 
##     data = ndat)
## Residuals:
##      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
## -3.45795 -0.68135  0.01051  0.71137  3.12018 
## 
## Correlation parameter estimates:
##                gamma     theta
## par. est. 0.28790545 0.3483397
## s.e.      0.05185003 0.1709134
## 
## Regression coefficients:
##             Value  Std. Error Z value Pr(>|Z|)
## (Intercept) 0.0836 0.0627     1.3335  0.1824  
## 
## MLE of resid. variance: 1.044 
## -2 log likelihood:  1398.87

Now we replicate the simulation process for 100 realizations.

n2 = replicate(100, simgst_bal_zeromean(.33, .5))

A report on the first replicate is:

rdec:::summary.rdec(n2[,1])
## 
## Call: rdec::rdec(formula = value ~ 1, id = ndat$Var1, S = ndat$Var2, 
##     data = ndat)
## Residuals:
##     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
## -2.6306 -0.6657  0.0261  0.6630  3.8667 
## 
## Correlation parameter estimates:
##                gamma     theta
## par. est. 0.28239226 0.3627128
## s.e.      0.05196461 0.1788009
## 
## Regression coefficients:
##             Value  Std. Error Z value Pr(>|Z|)
## (Intercept) 0.0830 0.0575     1.4430  0.1490  
## 
## MLE of resid. variance: 0.8944 
## -2 log likelihood:  1323.656

The distribution of estimates of \(\gamma\) can be obtained using

gams = apply(n2, 2, function(x) x$omega[1])
summary(gams)
##    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
##  0.2267  0.2878  0.3213  0.3220  0.3567  0.4561

The standard errors estimated by the procedure can be collected as follows:

getses = function(x) rdec:::summary.rdec(x)$se.omega
allses = apply(n2, 2, getses)

The standard errors should estimate the standard deviation of estimates over the simulation replicates.

sd(gams)
## [1] 0.04567117
summary(allses[1,])
##    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
## 0.04430 0.04844 0.05013 0.05010 0.05174 0.05576

The median s.e. estimate for \(\hat{\gamma}\) is close to the sampling s.d. for the estimates of \(\gamma\).
